text: Thanksgiving dinner is the most
celebrated meal of the year and
everybody wants a moist and delicious
turkey right of course well a method
that has been gaining popularity has
been brining but I find that brining
which is typically done with a solution
of water and salt
sometimes there's flavorings in it can
dilute the natural flavor of the turkey
so today I'm going to show you a new way
of brining and that incorporates a
little bit of buttermilk which helps to
tenderize and also to add some really
great flavor I have one quart of water
in a small sauce pot here and to that
I'm going to add one and a half cups of
kosher salt dissolve the salt and add
two tablespoons of coriander seeds adds
a nice bit of flavor six bay leaves if
you can find fresh bay leaves try to use
those they have much more flavor into
the pot a teaspoon of brown mustard
seeds you could certainly use regular
yellow mustard seeds a tablespoon of
fennel seeds that adds a nice anise
flavor and one tablespoon of juniper
berries they give that wonderful flavor
to gin that and a bunch of other herbs
and botanicals so that goes into this
water mixture and just pull this down to
room temperature and then we're ready to
make the rest of the brine so our
concentrated brine has cooled completely
and now I'm going to add that to 4
quarts of water so this is quite a bit
of liquid but you are going to need it
because we have an 18 to 20 pound bird
here and now it had buttermilk
buttermilk is cultured and it's
acidified so the acidity and the
cultures are going to help tenderize the
turkey this is 3 quarts it's very
similar to a fried chicken brine or that
buttermilk mixture that you soak the
chicken in it really helps with a flavor
and a wonderful juicy moist texture to
your fried chicken so same principle
here now add 1 sliced onion this is for
added flavor
you can just kind of throw it on top of
the turkey I have the turkey in a
brining bag you can use a brining bag or
an oven bag something that you don't
mind throwing away one bunch of time
this is the hefty bunch of time and you
can kind of just break it apart and
scatter it around the bird and six
garlic cloves that have been crushed
again this is just for flavor now I'm
going to transfer into a vessel that
will hold the turkey and all of that
brining liquid
some people use coolers some people use
pots anything that will hold the turkey
the brine and the bag all together so
now it's time to pour over the brine and
you need a little bit of muscle here so
the last bit of brine here and now with
this bag just give it a tie with some
kitchen twine making sure that the brine
is covering the entire bird this goes
into the refrigerator for about 24 hours
a general rule of thumb when brining for
every pound of meat you have you need
one full hour of brining time so this
turkey is 18 to 20 pounds so it's gonna
go into the refrigerator for about a
full day but based on whatever weight
you have you can adjust the time so into
the refrigerator so here we have it now
pull your turkey out of the refrigerator
for about an hour
discard the brine rinse your turkey Pat
it dry and then trust it however you
like I like to tuck the wingtips under
so that they don't burn in the oven and
secure the legs together so that the
turkey is a nice compact shape which
will help it to roast evenly now
pre-heat your oven to 400 degrees this
is going into that 400 degree oven for
45 minutes and then you reduce the
temperature to 325 for about two to two
and a half hours rotating and basting
with juices until the turkey is done and
that is 165 degrees in
the thickest part of the thigh avoiding
the bone so this is going right into the
oven you're going to see how beautiful
it looks when it comes out so our turkey
is out of the oven it's golden-brown its
moist it's perfectly cooked and it's
tasty and delicious I promise you so if
you're gonna brine this year try this
buttermilk brine I'm sure that you will
love it
happy cooking
you
